ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the literary magazine scene and what it could mean to build a career as a writer, editor, or to work in publishing or on a magazine.

learned a lot about the literary world and existing landscape! this class felt pre-professional in a lot of ways but never in a competitive or (too) anxiety-inducing awayit was a great way of talking to industry professionals and learning about the inner workings of literary magazines and reading some interesting pieces from those magazines

I learnt about the historical and contemporary landscape of literary magazines in America. We read essays, reviews, and fiction, and discussed the traits of each piece of prose and how they fit the character of a particular magazine. Towards the end of the semester, we also looked at writing heds/deks and writing for social media.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: the readings were interesting, sam was a great seminar leader, and all the guest speakers were cool. the class got more fun in the last few weeks once we knew each other better too.

weakness: sometimes the reading was a bit too much and it was hard to know what to focus onit might help to cut the readings by 33% next time this class is taught. i also wish we got to write a little more!

The strength of this class included reading and evaluating real submissions for TYR, the quality of the readings, and the guest speakers who attended class. Perhaps discussions about the practice of editing and developing skills such as writing heds/deks/social lines could have been introduced earlier in the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I would definitely recommend if you are at all interested in literary magazines, writing, editing, or working in publishing. This class was so interesting and we had so many cool writers and editors come to speak to us. I loved all of the readings, the discussions were always interesting, and reading submissions for The Yale Review helped me build an important skillset and critical eye as both an editor and writer.
yes if you are interested in working or writing for a literary magazine! you'll just learn so much.
